'''Jackery''' is a technology company based in [[Fremont, California]], that manufactures [[portable power]] stations and [[solar panel]]s. Founded in 2012, the company emerged during the early commercial development of solar generators for outdoor recreation and emergency home backup.<ref>{{cite web |title=PV goes portable: The history of solar generators |url=https://pv-magazine-usa.com/2024/02/22/pv-goes-portable/ |publisher=PV Magazine USA |accessdate=2026-02-06}}</ref>

[https://www.jackery.com Jackery] Inc. is a company that develops and manufactures portable power and green energy solutions.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |title=Jackery {{!}} LinkedIn |url=https://www.linkedin.com/company/jackery |access-date=2025-10-22 |website=www.linkedin.com |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Jackery 2025 Company Profile: Valuation, Funding & Investors {{!}} PitchBook |url=https://pitchbook.com/profiles/company/222474-61 |access-date=2025-10-22 |website=pitchbook.com |language=en}}</ref> Founded in California in 2012, the company specializes in portable power stations, solar panels, and solar generators designed for outdoor, off-grid, and home emergency backup use.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Portable Power Station Market Size {{!}} Industry Report, 2030 |url=https://www.grandviewresearch.com/industry-analysis/portable-power-station-market-report |access-date=2025-10-22 |website=www.grandviewresearch.com |language=en}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web |title=Jackery |url=https://www.hello-tech.com/en/jackery |access-date=2025-10-22 |website=www.hello-tech.com |language=en-US}}</ref> Jackery is owned by [https://www.hello-tech.com/en/jackery Shenzhen Hello Tech Energy Co., Ltd.].


== History ==
== History ==
The company was established in 2012 in [[Silicon Valley]] by Zhuo Sun, a former [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] engineer with experience in battery technology development.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Apple Of Portable Power Devices |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidhochman/2022/11/07/the-apple-of-portable-power-devices/ |publisher=Forbes |author=Hochman, David |date=2022-11-07 |accessdate=2026-02-06}}</ref> The company initially produced mobile battery accessories before shifting to outdoor portable power stations in 2016.<ref>{{cite web |title=Jackery Leaf iPhone 5 & 5S backup battery review |url=https://the-gadgeteer.com/2014/02/12/jackery-leaf-iphone-5-5s-backup-battery-review/ |publisher=The Gadgeteer |author=Geisz, Larry |date=2014-02-12 |accessdate=2026-02-06}}</ref> Subsequently, Jackery expanded its retail distribution in the United States to include major retailers such as [[Target Corporation|Target]] and [[Costco]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Jackery rolls out solar generators in 500 Target stores |url=https://www.retail-insight-network.com/news/jackery-target-generators-stores/ |publisher=Retail Insight Network |date=2024-04-22 |accessdate=2026-02-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Costco's Budget Generator Is A Portable Power Upgrade |url=https://www.explore.com/1943387/jackery-1000-plus-solar-panel-generator-costco-budget-camping-upgrade-portable-power/ |publisher=Explore.com |date=2024-01-10 |accessdate=2026-02-06}}</ref>
Jackery was founded in Silicon Valley, California, in 2012 by a group of engineers with the goal of making renewable energy more accessible.<ref>{{Cite web |title=About us |url=https://eu.jackery.com/pages/about-us |access-date=2025-10-22 |website=Jackery EU |language=en}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web |last=Hochman |first=David |title=The Apple Of Portable Power Devices |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidhochman/2022/11/07/the-apple-of-portable-power-devices/ |access-date=2025-10-22 |website=Forbes |language=en}}</ref>

In 2016, the company launched its first lithium portable power station, the Explorer series.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |title=About Us |url=https://www.jackery.com/pages/about-us |access-date=2025-10-22 |website=Jackery |language=en}}</ref> That same year, the product line received both the German Red Dot Design Award and the iF Design Award.<ref name=":3" />

Two years later, in 2018 Jackery introduced its first portable solar panels, the SolarSaga series, creating the concept of a "solar generator" by bundling them with its power stations.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The SolarSaga series was recognized with a CES Innovation Award that year.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web |date=2022-12-07 |title=The Portable Power Revolution |url=https://partners.wsj.com/jackery/marking-a-decade-of-engineering-the-portable-power-revolution/ |access-date=2025-10-22 |website=Jackery |language=en-US}}</ref>

The company has reported significant sales growth, having sold over 2 million units worldwide by 2022,<ref name=":2" /> over 3 million by 2023,<ref>{{Cite web |date=2025-08-01 |title=Jackery's 2023: A Year of Unparalleled Growth, Recognition, and Environmental Impact |url=https://www.jackery.com/blogs/news/jackery-2023-growth-recognition-impact |access-date=2025-10-22 |website=Jackery |language=en}}</ref> and surpassing 5 million units by late 2024.<ref name=":0" />


== Awards and recognition ==
== Products ==
The company's products utilize [[lithium-ion battery|lithium-ion]] and [[lithium iron phosphate battery|lithium iron phosphate]] (LiFePO4) batteries. Key product lines include:
Jackery has been recognized by over 200 media outlets, including ''The New York Times''<ref>{{cite news |last1=Witman |first1=Sarah |title=The Best Portable Power Station |url=https://www.nytimes.com/wirecutter/reviews/best-portable-power-stations/?searchResultPosition=1 |access-date=19 November 2025 |work=The New York Times |date=14 July 2025 |quote=If portability is your primary concern, the Jackery Explorer 300 is your best bet.}}</ref> and ''Forbes''.<ref name=":2" /> The company has received numerous international awards for its products, including:
* '''Explorer Series''': Portable power stations.
* '''SolarSaga Series''': Portable solar panels.
* '''Solar Generators''': Packages combining power stations with solar panels.<ref>{{cite web |title=Volt Value: Jackery Solar Generator Explorer 500 + SolarSaga 100 Review |url=https://gearjunkie.com/technology/portable-power/volt-value-jackery-solar-generator-explorer-500-solarsaga-100-review |publisher=GearJunkie |author=Hunt, Steve |date=2023-05-23 |accessdate=2026-02-06}}</ref>


== Reception ==
* Red Dot Design Award (2016)<ref name=":3" />
''[[CNET]]'' named the Jackery Explorer 2000 Plus the "Best overall portable power station" of 2026.<ref>{{cite web |title=Best Tested Portable Power Stations in 2026 |url=https://www.cnet.com/home/energy-and-utilities/best-portable-power-stations/ |publisher=CNET |accessdate=2026-02-05}}</ref> However, ''[[TechRadar]]'' noted in its review of the Solar Generator 1000 Pro that the price is higher than competitors, and criticized its non-standard solar input ports.<ref>{{cite web |title=Jackery Solar Generator 1000 Pro review |url=https://www.techradar.com/reviews/jackery-solar-generator-1000-pro |publisher=TechRadar |author=Burette, Julien |date=2022-11-22 |accessdate=2026-02-06}}</ref> In 2023, ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'' magazine named the company's "Solar Mars Bot" as one of the "Best Inventions of 2023".<ref>{{cite web |title=The Best Inventions of 2023: Jackery Solar Mars Bot |url=https://time.com/collection/best-inventions-2023/6324571/jackery-solar-mars-bot/ |publisher=TIME |date=2023-10-24 |accessdate=2026-02-06}}</ref>
* iF Design Award (2016)<ref name=":3" />
* CES Innovation Awards (2018, 2023)<ref name=":4" />
* TIME Best Inventions Award<ref name=":3" />
* SEAL Sustainable Product Award (2023, 2024)<ref>{{Cite press release |last=Inc |first=Jackery |title=Jackery's Commitment to Sustainability Recognized with SEAL Award for the Second Year |url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/jackerys-commitment-to-sustainability-recognized-with-seal-award-for-the-second-year-302187905.html |access-date=2025-10-22 |website=www.prnewswire.com |language=en}}</ref>
* Newsweek's America's Best Online Shops (2024)<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-06 |title=Jackery Named as One of America's Best Online Shops 2024 by Newsweek |url=https://www.jackery.com/blogs/news/jackery-named-as-one-of-americas-best-online-shops-2024-by-newsweek |access-date=2025-10-22 |website=Jackery |language=en}}</ref>

The genus ''[[Fonticula]]'' was continually excluded, as it was considered an [[Acrasidae|acrasid]]<ref name="Worley-1979">{{cite journal|first1=Ann C.|last1=Worley|first2=Kenneth B.|last2=Raper|first3=Marianne|last3=Hohl|title=''Fonticula alba'': a new cellular slime mold (Acrasiomycetes)|journal=Mycologia|volume=71|date=1979|issue=4|pages=746‚Äì760|doi=10.1080/00275514.1979.12021068}}</ref> or a [[slime mold]],<ref name="Deasey-1981">{{cite journal|first1=Mary C.|last1=Deasey|first2=Lindsay S.|last2=Olive|title=Role of Golgi apparatus in sorogenesis by the cellular slime mold ''Fonticula alba''|journal=Science|volume=213|issue=4507|pages=561‚Äì563|doi=10.1126/science.213.4507.561|date=31 July 1981|pmid=17794844 |bibcode=1981Sci...213..561D }}</ref> until 1993, when protozoologist [[Thomas Cavalier-Smith]] created the subclass '''Cristidiscoidia''' to house two orders: '''Nucleariida''' (with Nucleariidae and Pompholyxophryidae) and '''Fonticulida''' (with Fonticulidae).<ref name="Cavalier-Smith-1993">{{cite journal|last1=Cavalier-Smith|first1=Thomas|author-link=Thomas Cavalier-Smith|title=Kingdom Protozoa and its 18 phyla|journal=Microbiological Reviews|date=1993|volume=57 |pages=953‚Äì994|pmc=372943|pmid=8302218|doi= 10.1128/mr.57.4.953-994.1993|issue=4}}</ref><ref name="Gabald√≥n-2022"/> However, he later considered scaled nucleariids (Pompholyxophryidae) as members of the [[Cercozoa]], completely separate from naked ones,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cavalier-Smith|first1=Thomas|author-link=Thomas Cavalier-Smith|last2=Chao|first2=Ema E.|title=''Oxnerella micra'' sp. n. (Oxnerellidae fam. n.), a tiny naked centrohelid, and the diversity and evolution of Heliozoa|volume=163|issue=4|date=July 2012|pages=574‚Äì601|doi=10.1016/j.protis.2011.12.005|journal=Protist|pmid=22317961 }}</ref> but this is no longer accepted.<ref name="Galindo-2019"/> In a 1999 taxonomic revision by Kirill A. He also included ''[[Belonocystis]]''<ref name="Mikrjukov-1999">{{cite journal|first1=Kirill A.|last1=Mikrjukov|title=Taxonomic revision of scale-bearing heliozoon-like amoebae (Pompholyxophryidae, Rotosphaerida)|journal=Acta Protozoologica|volume=38|issue=2|pages=119‚Äì131|date=1999|url=https://rcin.org.pl/dlibra/publication/17718/edition/13534/content}}</ref> and ''[[Micronuclearia]]'' in this order,<ref name="Mikrjukov-2001">{{cite journal|last1=Mikrjukov|first1=Kirill A.|last2=Mylnikov|first2=Alexander P.|title=A study of the fine structure and the mitosis of a lamellicristate amoeba, ''Micronuclearia podoventralis'' gen. et sp. nov. Autism services: Reply

‚Üê Previous revision Revision as of 10:08, 6 February 2026
Line 287: Line 287:
::::::::{{tq|There are no convictions}} This is false. Hassan was charged and pled guilty to wire fraud for her role in the autism scheme, independently of Feeding Our Future. [https://www.irs.gov/compliance/criminal-investigation/six-additional-defendants-charged-one-defendant-pleads-guilty-in-ongoing-fraud-schemes] [[User:Astaire|Astaire]] ([[User talk:Astaire|talk]]) 11:40, 28 January 2026 (UTC)
::::::::{{tq|There are no convictions}} This is false. Hassan was charged and pled guilty to wire fraud for her role in the autism scheme, independently of Feeding Our Future. [https://www.irs.gov/compliance/criminal-investigation/six-additional-defendants-charged-one-defendant-pleads-guilty-in-ongoing-fraud-schemes] [[User:Astaire|Astaire]] ([[User talk:Astaire|talk]]) 11:40, 28 January 2026 (UTC)
:::::::::You've silently dropped that this is already mentioned. The sources either have reliability concerns, or the coverage is minimal to the point that all of the major sources ignored it. Hassan pled guilty, a single person, for ''wire fraud'' in an investigation that essentially overlaps with the Feeding our Future one, that is already covered. Per your own quote, emphasis on {{tq|in proportion to the prominence of each viewpoint in those sources}}. I would again suggest you read [[WP:NPOV]]. [[User:Lunarscarlet|Luna]] ([[User talk:Lunarscarlet|talk]]) 21:08, 28 January 2026 (UTC)
:::::::::You've silently dropped that this is already mentioned. The sources either have reliability concerns, or the coverage is minimal to the point that all of the major sources ignored it. Hassan pled guilty, a single person, for ''wire fraud'' in an investigation that essentially overlaps with the Feeding our Future one, that is already covered. Per your own quote, emphasis on {{tq|in proportion to the prominence of each viewpoint in those sources}}. I would again suggest you read [[WP:NPOV]]. [[User:Lunarscarlet|Luna]] ([[User talk:Lunarscarlet|talk]]) 21:08, 28 January 2026 (UTC)
::::::::::{{tq|You've silently dropped that this is already mentioned.}} I haven't "silently dropped" anything as I never discussed that fact in the first place.
::::::::::{{tq|The sources either have reliability concerns}} No they don't. The only "reliability concerns" have been a temp account complaining about a handful of random headlines ([[WP:HEADLINE]]) and sentences from the ''Minnesota Reformer''. Bias is not unreliability ([[WP:BIASED]]), and no concrete issues with the ''Reformer'''s factual accuracy have been presented.
::::::::::{{tq|the coverage is minimal to the point that all of the major sources ignored it}} This is false. The ''Star-Tribune'' has multiple articles specifically about autism fraud investigations [https://www.startribune.com/fbi-searching-autism-centers-in-minneapolis-st-cloud-after-finding-substantial-evidence-of-health-care-fraud/601194135] [https://www.startribune.com/woman-charged-with-defrauding-minnesota-autism-program-out-of-14-million-federal-prosecutors-say/601479954] [https://www.startribune.com/state-says-it-cant-say-whether-autism-centers-are-still-operating-after-fbi-raid/601196089] [https://www.startribune.com/minnesota-bolsters-oversight-of-autism-and-housing-programs-amid-fraud-concerns/601348314]. Sources that discuss the fraud scandals as a whole - ''Star-Tribune'' [https://www.startribune.com/heres-what-to-know-about-minnesotas-fraud-crisis/601542128], NYT [https://www.nytimes.com/2025/11/29/us/fraud-minnesota-somali.html], CBS News [https://www.cbsnews.com/news/minnesota-fraud-schemes-what-we-know/], and Axios [https://www.axios.com/2026/01/06/minnesota-fraud-cases-timeline] - all devote space to the autism fraud investigations.
::::::::::{{tq|Hassan pled guilty, a single person, for ''wire fraud''}} As opposed to some other kind of fraud? Have you noticed the word "fraud" in the title of this page?
::::::::::{{tq|an investigation that essentially overlaps with the Feeding our Future one}} The Hassan case is ''linked'' to Feeding Our Future, but it does not "overlap with" it, and the other autism fraud investigations have no link to FOF at all. [[User:Astaire|Astaire]] ([[User talk:Astaire|talk]]) 10:08, 6 February 2026 (UTC)
::::::Both the Star Tribune article and the Minnesota Reformer articles are news pieces. If the outlets are reliable we can source facts (like the 1 in 16 figure) from them, unless later reliable reporting refuted it. The question is whether it‚Äôs due. [[User:Bobfrombrockley|BobFromBrockley]] ([[User talk:Bobfrombrockley|talk]]) 08:19, 28 January 2026 (UTC)

A '''viseme''' is any of several [[speech sound]]s that look the same, for example when [[lip reading]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fisher |first1=Cletus G. |title=Confusions Among Visually Perceived Consonants |journal=Journal of Speech and Hearing Research |date=1 December 1968 |volume=11 |issue=4 |pages=796‚Äì804 |doi=10.1044/jshr.1104.796 |pmid=5719234 |url=https://pubs.asha.org/doi/10.1044/jshr.1104.796|url-access=subscription }}</ref>
A '''viseme''' is any of several [[speech sound]]s that look the same, for example when [[lip reading]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fisher |first1=Cletus G. |title=Confusions Among Visually Perceived Consonants |journal=Journal of Speech and Hearing Research |date=1 December 1968 |volume=11 |issue=4 |pages=796‚Äì804 |doi=10.1044/jshr.1104.796 |pmid=5719234 |url=https://pubs.asha.org/doi/10.1044/jshr.1104.796|url-access=subscription }}</ref>


Visemes and [[phonemes]] do not share a one-to-one correspondence. Often several phonemes correspond to a single viseme, as several phonemes look the same on the face when produced, such as {{IPA|/k, …°, ≈ã/}}; as well as {{IPA|/t, d, n, l/}} and {{IPA|/p, b, m/}}). Thus words such as ''pet, bell,'' and ''men'' are difficult for lip-readers to distinguish, as all look like alike. On one account, visemes offer (phonetic) information about place of articulation, while manner of articulation requires auditory input.<ref name="Summerfield92">{{cite journal |last1=Summerfield |first1=Quentin |title=Lipreading and audio-visual speech perception |journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B Biological Sciences|date=29 January 1992 |volume=335 |issue=1273 |pages=71‚Äì78 |doi=10.1098/rstb.1992.0009 |url=https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/10.1098/rstb.1992.0009 |eissn=1471-2970 |issn=0962-8436 |pmid=1348140|url-access=subscription }}</ref>
Visemes and [[phonemes]] do not share a one-to-one correspondence. Often several phonemes correspond to a single viseme, as several phonemes look the same on the face when produced, such as {{IPA|/k, …°, ≈ã/}}; as well as {{IPA|/t, d, n, l/}} and {{IPA|/p, b, m/}}). Thus words such as ''pet, bell,'' and ''men'' are difficult for lip-readers to distinguish, as all look like alike. On one account, visemes offer (phonetic) information about place of articulation, while manner of articulation requires auditory input.<ref name="Summerfield92">{{cite journal |last1=Summerfield |first1=Quentin |title=Lipreading and audio-visual speech perception |journal= Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B: Biological Sciences|date=29 January 1992 |volume=335 |issue=1273 |pages=71‚Äì78 |doi=10.1098/rstb.1992.0009 |url=https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/10.1098/rstb.1992.0009 |eissn=1471-2970 |issn=0962-8436 |pmid=1348140|url-access=subscription }}</ref>


However, there may be differences in timing and duration during natural speech in terms of the visual "signature" of a given gesture that cannot be captured by simply concatenating (stilled) images of each of the mouth patterns in sequence.<ref name="CalvertCampbell03">{{cite journal |last1=Calvert |first1=Gemma A. |last2=Campbell |first2=Ruth |title=Reading Speech from Still and Moving Faces: The Neural Substrates of Visible Speech |journal=Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience |date=1 January 2003 |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=57‚Äì70 |doi=10.1162/089892903321107828 |pmid=12590843|s2cid=14153329 }}</ref> Conversely, some sounds which are hard to distinguish acoustically are clearly distinguished by the face. For example, in spoken English {{IPA|/l/}} and {{IPA|/r/}} can often sound quite similar (especially in clusters, such as 'grass' vs. 'glass'), yet the visual information can disambiguate. Some [[linguistics|linguists]] have argued that speech is best understood as bimodal (aural and visual), and comprehension can be compromised if one of these two domains is absent.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=McGurk |first1=Harry |last2=MacDonald |first2=John |author1-link=Harry McGurk |title=Hearing lips and seeing voices |journal=Nature |date=23 December 1976 |volume=264 |issue=5588 |pages=746‚Äì748 |doi=10.1038/264746a0 |pmid=1012311 |bibcode=1976Natur.264..746M |url=https://doi.org/10.1038/264746a0|url-access=subscription }}</ref>
However, there may be differences in timing and duration during natural speech in terms of the visual "signature" of a given gesture that cannot be captured by simply concatenating (stilled) images of each of the mouth patterns in sequence.<ref name="CalvertCampbell03">{{cite journal |last1=Calvert |first1=Gemma A. |last2=Campbell |first2=Ruth |title=Reading Speech from Still and Moving Faces: The Neural Substrates of Visible Speech |journal=Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience |date=1 January 2003 |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=57‚Äì70 |doi=10.1162/089892903321107828 |pmid=12590843|s2cid=14153329 }}</ref> Conversely, some sounds which are hard to distinguish acoustically are clearly distinguished by the face. For example, in spoken English {{IPA|/l/}} and {{IPA|/r/}} can often sound quite similar (especially in clusters, such as 'grass' vs. 'glass'), yet the visual information can disambiguate. Some [[linguistics|linguists]] have argued that speech is best understood as bimodal (aural and visual), and comprehension can be compromised if one of these two domains is absent.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=McGurk |first1=Harry |last2=MacDonald |first2=John |author1-link=Harry McGurk |title=Hearing lips and seeing voices |journal=Nature |date=23 December 1976 |volume=264 |issue=5588 |pages=746‚Äì748 |doi=10.1038/264746a0 |pmid=1012311 |bibcode=1976Natur.264..746M |url=https://doi.org/10.1038/264746a0|url-access=subscription }}</ref>
